Award.AwardTitle: Genetic and Genomic Approaches to Understanding the Role of Auxin in Shoot Development
Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Paula McSteen (University of Missouri - Columbia)

CoPIs: Simon Malcomber (California State University - Long Beach), Andrea Gallavotti and Yunde Zhao (University of California - San Diego)

Senior Personnel: Naomi Altman and Reka Albert (The Pennsylvania State University)

Collaborator: Robert Schmidt (University of California - San Diego)

The hormone auxin regulates almost every aspect of plant growth and development, including leaf and flower formation, and stem and flower cluster (inflorescence) branching. The long-term goal of this project is to understand how shoot (the above ground portion of a plant) growth is regulated through pathways of auxin biosynthesis, transport and signal transduction, and the extent to which these mechanisms and interactions are conserved among the approximately 250,000 described species of flowering plants. Genes that function in auxin mediated shoot development will be identified and characterized using a combination of high throughput forward genetics in maize and comparative expression profiling in both maize and Arabidopsis. Reverse genetic analyses will be used to uncover the function of genes in these pathways that may not be apparent from forward genetic approaches alone. Gene function will be analyzed using transgenic reporter lines coupled with phenotypic, expression and genetic analyses of characterized mutants to assemble a network of genetic interactions. A gene regulatory network model will be built to integrate the data from expression profiling together with genetic and biochemical interaction studies. Phylogenetic characterization of identified gene families using available genomic data and genes isolated during the course of the research will provide a framework and series of testable hypotheses concerning the conservation and diversification of auxin mechanisms in all flowering plants. The findings from this project will lead to a better understanding of how auxin controls shoot growth and development in agronomically and economically important crops.

Through a series of training and outreach programs this project will provide opportunities for high school students, undergraduates, graduate students, and postdoctoral researchers to learn and apply a broad range of genetic, developmental, evolutionary, genomic, statistical, mathematical and bioinformatic tools. Annual summer workshops and exchange programs will augment inter-disciplinary plant science training and dialog across fields. Results from the project will be incorporated into the Botanical Society of America's Planting Science program (http://www.plantingscience.org/) to create online open-ended, inquiry-based educational materials focusing on the role of auxin and the interdisciplinary nature of plant biology for high school students across the nation. Materials from this project will provide new resources and tools to investigate the role played by auxin in plant growth and development across flowering plants, and new information and strategies for improving crop yield in diverse crop species.

Project data will be made available through the project website (http://www.auxinevodevo.org). In addition, mutant stocks will be available from the Maize Coop Stock Center (http://maizecoop.cropsci.uiuc.edu/), phenotypic and genetic data including map locations will be deposited at MaizeGDB (http://www.maizegdb.org/), expression profiling data will be deposited at the Plant Expression Database (http://www.plexdb.org/), phylogenetic trees will be deposited at TREEBASE (http://www.treebase.org) and sequences will be deposited in Genbank(http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/) and Plant GDB (http://www.plantgdb.org).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit

The plant growth hormone, auxin, is essential for many aspects of plant growth and development.  In this project, we focused on understanding how auxin is made, transported and sensed, to control the formation of vegetative and reproductive organs (tassel and ear) in maize (corn).  Maize is an important crop in the US and reproduction is the basis of yield.  If maize plants have less auxin, they make very few kernels and hence have drastically reduced yield.  Hence, auxin plays a fundamental role in crop yield and understanding its mechanism of action may allow yield to be improved.  In addition, we compared the role of auxin in maize (a monocot) to Arabidopsis (a model eudicot) which enabled us to understand the conservation and diversification of the role of auxin in development of all flowering plants.  The approach that we used was to identify the molecular components (genes) of the auxin pathway and find out what happened when these components are knocked out (mutants) to determine the function of these genes.  Methods used included forward genetics, reverse genetics, biochemistry, molecular and cellular biology, transcriptomics, phylogenetics and expression analyses.

Using forward genetics, we identified mutants which made no ears or tassels (barren stalk or barren inflorescence) and then mapped them to a chromosomal location in order to pinpoint the gene that was affected.  147 mutants were analyzed to determine if they were heritable.  71 mutants were mapped to 41 locations in the maize genome.  A major accomplishment of the project was the identification of six new genes by map based cloning and the determination of their mechanism of action by molecular, cellular, developmental and evolutionary analysis.  Two of the genes were new components of the auxin signaling machinery (Barren inflorescence1 and Barren inflorescence 4) and another gene (barren stalk2) functioned in ear development in response to auxin.  Three additional genes (tasselless1, tasselless3 and rotten ear) had completely unanticipated functions opening up new areas of research at the intersection between nutrition, hormone signaling and development.

Hundreds of genes were identified by determining, at a whole genome level, the genes that were differentially expressed in three mutants compared to normal in maize and in an auxin inducible system in Arabidopsis.  Statistical analysis included determining the methods which best summarized the data taking into account the biological variability in the samples.  Data visualization methods were used to identify genes that acted together to assist in the selection of genes and pathways for further study.

Phylogenetic analysis of the 15 gene families identified in the course of the work was carried out with all available plant genomes and expression analysis was carried out in multiple monocot and dicot species.  This enabled us to infer the functional relationships amongst the genes and to extend the implications to all flowering plants.  From this work, we discovered extensive sub-functionalization of gene family members at the level of gene expression.  In addition to expression patterns, we also determined the protein interaction partners of members of the auxin signaling pathway in maize, and the genome-wide DNA binding landscape of Auxin Response Factors in both maize and Arabidopsis using a newly developed technique for transcription factor binding site identification.

Genes identified by transcriptome and phylogenetic analysis were analyzed by reverse genetics, which means to identify the genes first and then determine the function by knocking out the gene (mainly using transposons) in both maize and Arabidopsis.  103 transposon insertions in 47 genes were identified and confirmed.  From the forward and reverse genetics, the conclusion was that genetic regulation of the pathway was more complex than expected with a high level of genetic redundancy.  Furthermore, the research in Arabidopsis discovered some unexpected genetic phenomena. 

The results from this project were published in 20 publications (many in very high profile journals), seven Masters of Science dissertations and four PhD theses, and are available on publically accessible websites such as MaizeGDB and www.auxinevodevo.org.  Seed of all mutants are available from the Maize Coop.

Broader impacts

In total, the labs on the project trained 7 postdocs, 8 technicians, 17 graduate students and 31 undergraduate students, at 5 institutions across the country (CA, MO, PA, NJ), in interdisciplinary aspects of plant physiology, molecular, cellular and developmental biology, computer science and evolutionary analysis.  We developed a module for K-12 education, a mapping module for the Cold Spring Harbor Lab Plant Science course (2012-14) and a mapping workshop for the Maize Genetics Conference in Beijing (2014), extending the knowledge that we obtained to the broader community.  We held three training workshops on molecular mapping, phylogenetic analysis, and expression profiling to enhance the training of members of the consortium and additional students at the same institutions.  The workshop materials and training modules are available on our website.
